# Important Information for the query
External Knowledge: 
-- mjd date for December = 59914.0
-- mjd date for September = 60217.0
Domain Knowledge: 
-- Super Nova (SNe) is a large explosion that takes place at the end of a star's life cycle

 # User Request: ''Give me all the SNe that were first detected between december first 2022 and september first 2023. Return the probability class, the last and the first detection date and the oids of the objects.''

system.text:
# As a SQL expert with a willingness to assist users, you are tasked with crafting a PostgreSQL query for the Automatic Learning for the Rapid Classification of Events (ALeRCE) Database in 2023. This database serves as a repository for information about individual spatial objects, encompassing various statistics, properties, detections, and features observed by survey telescopes.
The tables within the database are categorized into three types: time and band independent (e.g., object, probability), time-independent (e.g., magstats), and time and band-dependent (e.g., detection). Your role involves carefully analyzing user requests, considering the specifics of the given tables. It is crucial to pay attention to explicit conditions outlined by the user and always maintain awareness of the broader context.
ALeRCE processes data from the alert stream of the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF), so unless a specific catalog is mentioned, the data is from ZTF, including the object, candidate and filter identifiers, and other relevant information.  
Be thorough in understanding and addressing the user's request, taking into account both explicit conditions and the overall context for effective communication and assistance.


# The Database has the following tables that can be used to generate the SQL query:

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);


CREATE TABLE dataquality (
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique identifier for the subtraction candidate */
    oid VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* unique identifier for this object */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* Filter ID (1=g; 2=r; 3=i) */
    xpos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* x-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    ypos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* y-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    chipsf DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Reduced chi-square for PSF-fit */
    sky DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Local sky background estimate [DN] */
    fwhm DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Full Width Half Max assuming a Gaussian core, from SExtractor [pixels] */
    classtar DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Star/Galaxy classification score from SExtractor */
    mindtoedge DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Distance to nearest edge in image [pixels] */
    seeratio DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: difffwhm / fwhm */
    aimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat major axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    bimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat minor axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    aimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: aimage / fwhm */
    bimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: bimage / fwhm */
    nneg INTEGER, /* number of negative pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    nbad INTEGER, /* number of prior-tagged bad pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    sumrat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: sum(pixels) / sum(abs(pixels)) in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp where stamp is first median-filtered to mitigate outliers */
    scorr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Peak-pixel signal-to-noise ratio in point source matched-filtered detection image */
    dsnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: D/stddev(D) on event position where D = difference image */
    ssnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: S/stddev(S) on event position where S = image of convolution: D (x) PSF(D) */
    magzpsci DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point for photometry estimates [mag] */
    magzpsciunc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point uncertainty (in magzpsci) [mag] */
    magzpscirms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS (deviation from average) in all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    nmatches INTEGER, /* Number of PS1 photometric calibrators used to calibrate science image from science image processing */
    clrcoeff DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient from linear fit from photometric calibration of science image */
    clrcounc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient uncertainty from linear fit (corresponding to clrcoeff) */
    zpclrcov DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Covariance in magzpsci and clrcoeff from science image processing [mag^2] */
    zpmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point from median of all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    clrmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Median color of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag]: for filter (fid) = 1, 2, 3, PS1 color used = g-r, g-r, r-i respectively */
    clrrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS color (deviation from average) of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag] */
    exptime DOUBLE PRECISION /* Integration time of camera exposure [sec] */
    FOREIGN KEY (candid, oid) REFERENCES detection(candid, oid)
);




## DEFAULT CONDITIONS YOU NEED TO SET
### IF THE 'probability' TABLE is used, use always the next conditions, unless the user explicitly specifies different probability conditions.
- 'probability.ranking' = 1 ; this only return the most likely probabilities, if the user request all ranking probabilities, don't use it.
- 'probability.classifier_name='lc_classifier' ; this will return the classifications by the light curve classifier
### GENERAL
### Important points to consider
- If the user doesn't specify explicit columns or information that is not in a column, choose all the columns, for example by using the “SELECT *” SQL statement, from ALL the tables used, including the ones from the sub-queries.
- Mantain the EXACT COLUMN names as they are in the database, unless the user explicitly asks you to do so in the request, giving you the new name to use. This is crucial for the query to work correctly.
- Mantain the exact class names as they are in the database, marked with single quotes, for example, 'SNIa'.

# If you need to use 2 tables, try using a INNER JOIN statement, or a sub-query over 'probability' or 'object', if the query requires it. It is important to be really careful with the use of sub-queries or JOINs, as they can slow down the query.
# Answer ONLY with the SQL query, do not include any additional or explanatory text. If you want to add something, add COMMENTS IN PostgreSQL format so that the user can understand.
# Answer ONLY with the final SQL query, with the following format: 
  ```sql SQL_QUERY_HERE ```
DON'T include anything else in your answer. If you want to add comments, use the SQL comment format inside the query.

# Use the next decomposed planification to write the query:
To generate the PostgreSQL query to retrieve the requested information, we can follow these steps:

1. **Understand the Database Schema:**
   - The main table that contains the information about the objects is the `object` table.
   - The `probability` table contains the classification probabilities for each object.
   - The relevant columns are `oid`, `firstmjd`, `lastmjd`, and the columns related to the classification probabilities.

2. **Define the Information Needed:**
   - The user is requesting information about Supernovae (SNe) that were first detected between December 1, 2022 and September 1, 2023.
   - The required information includes the probability class, the first and last detection dates, and the object IDs (oids).

3. **Formulate the Query Requirements:**
   - We need to filter the objects based on the `firstmjd` column, which represents the time of the first detection.
   - We want to retrieve the objects that have a classification probability with `class_name` equal to 'SNIa', 'SNIbc', 'SNII', or 'SLSN', which are the Supernova classes.
   - We need to join the `object` and `probability` tables to access both the object information and the classification probabilities.
   - We want to return the `oid`, `firstmjd`, `lastmjd`, and the relevant probability columns.

4. **Design the Query:**
   - Start with the `object` table as the main table.
   - Join the `probability` table using an `INNER JOIN` on the `oid` column.
   - Add a `WHERE` clause to filter the `firstmjd` column between the specified dates (December 1, 2022 and September 1, 2023).
   - Add a `WHERE` clause to filter the `class_name` to the desired Supernova classes ('SNIa', 'SNIbc', 'SNII', 'SLSN').
   - Use the default conditions for the `probability` table, which are `probability.ranking = 1` and `probability.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'`.
   - Select the desired columns: `object.oid`, `object.firstmjd`, `object.lastmjd`, `probability.class_name`, `probability.probability`.

5. **Document the Query:**
   - The query will retrieve all Supernova objects that were first detected between December 1, 2022 and September 1, 2023.
   - It will return the object ID (`oid`), the first and last detection dates (`firstmjd` and `lastmjd`), the Supernova class name (`class_name`), and the probability of that classification (`probability`).
   - The query will use the default conditions for the `probability` table, which are the most likely classification (`probability.ranking = 1`) and the light curve classifier (`probability.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'`).
   - The query will join the `object` and `probability` tables to access both the object information and the classification probabilities.
# If there is SQL code, use it only as reference, changing the conditions you consider necessary.
# You can join some of the steps if you consider it better for the query. For example, if 2 or more use the same table and are not requested to be different sub-queries, then you can join them.

 # User Request: ''Get the object identifiers and probabilities in the light curve classifier for objects classified in the light curve classifier as SNIa with ranking=1 and CV/Nova with ranking=2, where the difference between the probabilities at each ranking is lower than 0.1. To generate the PostgreSQL query that fulfills the user's request, we can follow these steps:

1. **Identify the Relevant Tables**: The main tables involved in this query are `object` and `probability`.

2. **Understand the Query Requirements**:
   - The user wants to retrieve object identifiers (oids) and probabilities for objects classified as 'SNIa' with ranking 1 and 'CV/Nova' with ranking 2 in the 'lc_classifier'.
   - The difference between the probabilities for the two classes should be less than 0.1.
   - The desired output should include the oid, the probability for 'SNIa' (named 'SN_prob'), and the probability for 'CV/Nova' (named 'CV_prob').

3. **Design the Query**:
   a. Start with the `probability` table to get the classification information.
   b. Add a `WHERE` clause to filter for 'SNIa' and 'CV/Nova' classes with the specified rankings.
   c. Use an `INNER JOIN` with the `object` table to get the oid.
   d. Add a `WHERE` clause to ensure the difference between the two probabilities is less than 0.1.

4. **Construct the Query**:
   - The query will start with the `probability` table to get the classification information.
   - Add an `INNER JOIN` with the `object` table to get the oid.
   - Use `WHERE` clauses to filter for the specific class names, rankings, and probability difference.
   - Select the oid, the probability for 'SNIa' (named 'SN_prob'), and the probability for 'CV/Nova' (named 'CV_prob').

5. **Document the Query**:

   - Describe any assumptions or limitations of the query.

The final query will look something like this:

```sql
-- Retrieve object identifiers and probabilities for SNIa (rank 1) and CV/Nova (rank 2) in the lc_classifier
-- where the difference between the probabilities is less than 0.1
SELECT
  o.oid,
  p1.probability AS SN_prob,
  p2.probability AS CV_prob
FROM
  probability p1
  INNER JOIN probability p2 ON p1.oid = p2.oid
  INNER JOIN object o ON p1.oid = o.oid
WHERE
  p1.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'
  AND p1.class_name = 'SNIa'
  AND p1.ranking = 1
  AND p2.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'
  AND p2.class_name = 'CV/Nova'
  AND p2.ranking = 2
  AND ABS(p1.probability - p2.probability) < 0.1
```

This database serves as a repository for information about individual spatial objects, encompassing various statistics, properties, detections, and features observed by survey telescopes.
The tables within the database are categorized into three types: time and band independent (e.g., object, probability), time-independent (e.g., magstats), and time and band-dependent (e.g., detection). ALeRCE processes data from the alert stream of the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF), so unless a specific catalog is mentioned, the data is from ZTF, including the object, candidate and filter identifiers, and other relevant information.

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);


CREATE TABLE dataquality (
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique identifier for the subtraction candidate */
    oid VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* unique identifier for this object */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* Filter ID (1=g; 2=r; 3=i) */
    xpos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* x-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    ypos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* y-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    chipsf DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Reduced chi-square for PSF-fit */
    sky DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Local sky background estimate [DN] */
    fwhm DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Full Width Half Max assuming a Gaussian core, from SExtractor [pixels] */
    classtar DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Star/Galaxy classification score from SExtractor */
    mindtoedge DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Distance to nearest edge in image [pixels] */
    seeratio DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: difffwhm / fwhm */
    aimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat major axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    bimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat minor axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    aimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: aimage / fwhm */
    bimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: bimage / fwhm */
    nneg INTEGER, /* number of negative pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    nbad INTEGER, /* number of prior-tagged bad pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    sumrat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: sum(pixels) / sum(abs(pixels)) in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp where stamp is first median-filtered to mitigate outliers */
    scorr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Peak-pixel signal-to-noise ratio in point source matched-filtered detection image */
    dsnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: D/stddev(D) on event position where D = difference image */
    ssnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: S/stddev(S) on event position where S = image of convolution: D (x) PSF(D) */
    magzpsci DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point for photometry estimates [mag] */
    magzpsciunc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point uncertainty (in magzpsci) [mag] */
    magzpscirms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS (deviation from average) in all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    nmatches INTEGER, /* Number of PS1 photometric calibrators used to calibrate science image from science image processing */
    clrcoeff DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient from linear fit from photometric calibration of science image */
    clrcounc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient uncertainty from linear fit (corresponding to clrcoeff) */
    zpclrcov DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Covariance in magzpsci and clrcoeff from science image processing [mag^2] */
    zpmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point from median of all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    clrmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Median color of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag]: for filter (fid) = 1, 2, 3, PS1 color used = g-r, g-r, r-i respectively */
    clrrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS color (deviation from average) of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag] */
    exptime DOUBLE PRECISION /* Integration time of camera exposure [sec] */

# Use the next decomposed planification to write the query:
To generate the PostgreSQL query that fulfills the user's request, we can follow these steps:

1. **Identify the Relevant Tables and Columns:**
   - The main table is `object`, which contains the general information about the objects.
   - The `probability` table contains the classification probabilities for the objects.
   - The `detection` table holds the individual detection information, including magnitudes, magnitude errors, and time of detection.
   - The `magstat` table provides additional statistics for the objects, including the initial rise estimate.

2. **Construct the Main Query:**
   - Start with the `object` table as the main table.
   - Join the `probability` table to filter the objects classified as 'SNII' with a probability greater than 0.6.
   - Join the `detection` table to retrieve the candidate identifier, magnitudes, magnitude errors, and band identifiers.
   - Join the `magstat` table to get the initial rise estimate.
   - Add filters for the time range (2019-2022), initial rise rate greater than 0.5 mag/day in g and r-bands, and number of detections greater than 50.

3. **Step-by-Step Query Decomposition:**
   a. Create a subquery on the `probability` table to get the objects classified as 'SNII' with probability greater than 0.6:
      ```
      SELECT oid
      FROM probability
      WHERE class_name = 'SNII'
        AND probability > 0.6
        AND classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'
        AND ranking = 1;
      ```
   b. Join the `object` table with the `probability` subquery to get the objects that match the classification criteria:
      ```
      SELECT o.*
      FROM object o
      INNER JOIN (
        SELECT oid
        FROM probability
        WHERE class_name = 'SNII'
          AND probability > 0.6
          AND classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'
          AND ranking = 1
      ) p ON o.oid = p.oid
      ```
   c. Join the `detection` table to retrieve the candidate identifier, magnitudes, magnitude errors, and band identifiers for the filtered objects:
      ```
      SELECT o.oid, d.candid, d.magpsf, d.sigmapsf, d.magpsf_corr, d.sigmapsf_corr, d.fid
      FROM (
        SELECT o.*
        FROM object o
        INNER JOIN (
          SELECT oid
          FROM probability
          WHERE class_name = 'SNII'
            AND probability > 0.6
            AND classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'
            AND ranking = 1
        ) p ON o.oid = p.oid
      ) o
      INNER JOIN detection d ON o.oid = d.oid
      ```
   d. Join the `magstat` table to get the initial rise estimate:
      ```
      SELECT o.oid, d.candid, d.magpsf, d.sigmapsf, d.magpsf_corr, d.sigmapsf_corr, d.fid, m.dmdt_first
      FROM (
        SELECT o.*
        FROM object o
        INNER JOIN (
          SELECT oid
          FROM probability
          WHERE class_name = 'SNII'
            AND probability > 0.6
            AND classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'
            AND ranking = 1
        ) p ON o.oid = p.oid
      ) o
      INNER JOIN detection d ON o.oid = d.oid
      INNER JOIN magstat m ON o.oid = m.oid AND d.fid = m.fid
      ```
   e. Add the final filters for the time range, initial rise rate, and number of detections:
      ```
      SELECT o.oid, d.candid, d.magpsf, d.sigmapsf, d.magpsf_corr, d.sigmapsf_corr, d.fid, m.dmdt_first
      FROM (
        SELECT o.*
        FROM object o
        INNER JOIN (
          SELECT oid
          FROM probability
          WHERE class_name = 'SNII'
            AND probability > 0.6
            AND classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'
            AND ranking = 1
        ) p ON o.oid = p.oid
        WHERE o.firstmjd BETWEEN '2019-01-01'::DOUBLE PRECISION AND '2022-12-31'::DOUBLE PRECISION
          AND o.ndet > 50
      ) o
      INNER JOIN detection d ON o.oid = d.oid
      INNER JOIN magstat m ON o.oid = m.oid AND d.fid = m.fid
      WHERE m.dmdt_first > 0.5
      ```

The final query will retrieve the object identifier, candidate identifier, magnitudes, magnitude errors, initial rise estimate, and band identifiers as a function of time for the objects classified as SN II in the year 2019-2022, with probability larger than 0.6, initial rise rate greater than 0.5 mag/day in ZTF g and r-band, and number of detections greater than 50.

# As a SQL expert with a willingness to assist users, you are tasked with crafting a PostgreSQL query for the Automatic Learning for the Rapid Classification of Events (ALeRCE) Database in 2023. This database serves as a repository for information about individual spatial objects, encompassing various statistics, properties, detections, and features observed by survey telescopes.
The tables within the database are categorized into three types: time and band independent (e.g., object, probability), time-independent (e.g., magstats), and time and band-dependent (e.g., detection). Your role involves carefully analyzing user requests, considering the specifics of the given tables. It is crucial to pay attention to explicit conditions outlined by the user and always maintain awareness of the broader context.
ALeRCE processes data from the alert stream of the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF), so unless a specific catalog is mentioned, the data is from ZTF, including the object, candidate and filter identifiers, and other relevant information.  
Be thorough in understanding and addressing the user's request, taking into account both explicit conditions and the overall context for effective communication and assistance.


# The Database has the following tables that can be used to generate the SQL query:

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);

    chipsf DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Reduced chi-square for PSF-fit */
    sky DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Local sky background estimate [DN] */
    fwhm DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Full Width Half Max assuming a Gaussian core, from SExtractor [pixels] */
    classtar DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Star/Galaxy classification score from SExtractor */
    mindtoedge DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Distance to nearest edge in image [pixels] */
    seeratio DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: difffwhm / fwhm */
    aimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat major axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    bimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat minor axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    aimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: aimage / fwhm */
    bimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: bimage / fwhm */
    nneg INTEGER, /* number of negative pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    nbad INTEGER, /* number of prior-tagged bad pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    sumrat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: sum(pixels) / sum(abs(pixels)) in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp where stamp is first median-filtered to mitigate outliers */
    scorr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Peak-pixel signal-to-noise ratio in point source matched-filtered detection image */

    clrcounc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient uncertainty from linear fit (corresponding to clrcoeff) */

To generate the PostgreSQL query to retrieve the requested information, we can follow these steps:

2. **Define the Columns to Retrieve**: The user request is asking for the object identifiers (`oid`) and the probabilities from the stamp classifier. Therefore, the columns needed are `oid`, `class_name`, `probability`, and `classifier_name`.

   - Filter for objects that had their first detection in January 2023. This can be done by checking that `object.firstmjd` is between the start and end of January 2023 (59945.0 and 59975.0).

4. **Construct the Query**:

   - Use an `INNER JOIN` between the `object` and `probability` tables to connect the object information with the classification probabilities.
   - Add `WHERE` clauses to filter the results based on the conditions:

     - `probability.class_name = 'SN'` to filter for Supernova class
     - `probability.classifier_name = 'stamp_classifier'` to use the stamp classifier
     - `object.firstmjd BETWEEN 59945.0 AND 59975.0` to filter for objects detected in January 2023.

SELECT 
  object.oid,
  probability.probability,
  probability.classifier_name

WHERE
  probability.ranking = 1
  AND probability.class_name = 'SN'
  AND probability.classifier_name = 'stamp_classifier'
  AND object.firstmjd BETWEEN 59945.0 AND 59975.0;
```

This query will retrieve the object identifiers, probabilities, and classifier name for objects whose most likely class according to the stamp classifier is 'SN' and had their first detection in January 2023.

  -- Retrieve all columns from the probability table
  p.*,
  -- Retrieve relevant columns from the object table
  o.oid, o.meanra, o.meandec
FROM 
  probability p
  INNER JOIN object o ON p.oid = o.oid
WHERE
  p.class_name IN ('SNIa', 'SNIbc', 'SNII', 'SLSN')
  AND p.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'
  AND p.probability > 0.2
ORDER BY
  p.ranking;
```

This query will return all the classification probabilities (with their rankings) for the requested classes, along with the relevant object information, such as the object identifier, right ascension, and declination.

1. **Identify the Relevant Tables**: The main tables involved in this query are `object` and `probability`.

   - Use the `probability` table to filter for objects with a `class_name` of `'RRL'` (RR Lyrae) and a `probability` greater than 0.55.

4. **Filter by Number of Detections**:
   - Add a `WHERE` clause to filter the results to only include objects with `object.ndet` greater than or equal to 100.

SELECT 
    o.oid, 
    o.meanra, 
    o.meandec, 
    o.ndet, 
    p.probability
FROM 
    object o
    INNER JOIN probability p ON o.oid = p.oid
WHERE 
    p.class_name = 'RRL' 
    AND p.probability > 0.55
    AND p.ranking = 1
    AND p.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'
    AND o.ndet >= 100

# Use the next decomposed planification to write the query:
To generate the PostgreSQL query for the given user request, we can follow these steps:

1. **Identify the Relevant Tables**:
   - The main table to use is the `object` table, as it contains the core information about the astronomical objects.
   - The `probability` table will be used to filter the objects based on the light curve classifier probabilities.

2. **Formulate the Query Requirements**:
   - The user wants to retrieve objects that are most likely to be RR Lyrae (RRL) stars, with a probability larger than 0.55 from the light curve classifier.
   - The objects should have 100 or more detections.

3. **Design the Query**:
   - Start with the `object` table as the main table.
   - Join the `probability` table to filter the objects based on the light curve classifier probabilities.
   - Apply the following conditions:
     - `probability.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'`: This ensures we use the light curve classifier probabilities.
     - `probability.class_name = 'RRL'`: This filters for RR Lyrae objects.
     - `probability.probability > 0.55`: This filters for objects with a probability greater than 0.55.
     - `probability.ranking = 1`: This ensures we only get the most likely classification for each object.
   - Add a filter on the `object.ndet` column to only include objects with 100 or more detections.
   - Select the desired columns from the `object` and `probability` tables, such as `oid`, `meanra`, `meandec`, `ndet`, `probability.probability`.

4. **Document the Query**:
   - Add comments to explain the purpose of the query and the meaning of the different parts.
   - Describe any assumptions or limitations of the query.

The detailed steps to generate the PostgreSQL query are as follows:

1. **Select the Relevant Columns**:
   - Select the columns from the `object` table that are needed, such as `oid`, `meanra`, `meandec`, `ndet`.
   - Select the `probability` column from the `probability` table.

2. **Join the `object` and `probability` Tables**:
   - Use an `INNER JOIN` to connect the `object` and `probability` tables based on the `oid` column.

3. **Apply the Filtering Conditions**:
   - Filter the `probability` table to only include rows where `classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'` and `class_name = 'RRL'`.
   - Filter the `probability` table to only include rows where `probability > 0.55` and `ranking = 1`.
   - Filter the `object` table to only include rows where `ndet >= 100`.

4. **Order the Results**:
   - Order the results by the `probability.probability` column in descending order to show the most likely RR Lyrae objects first.

5. **Document the Query**:
   - Add comments to explain the purpose of the query and the meaning of the different parts.
   - Describe any assumptions or limitations of the query.

The final query would look something like this (without the actual SQL code):

```
-- Query objects classified by the light curve classifier that are most likely to be RRL with a probability larger than 0.55 and that have 100 or more detections.
SELECT 
  o.oid,
  o.meanra,
  o.meandec,
  o.ndet,
  p.probability
FROM object o
INNER JOIN probability p ON o.oid = p.oid
WHERE 
  p.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'
  AND p.class_name = 'RRL'
  AND p.probability > 0.55
  AND p.ranking = 1
  AND o.ndet >= 100
ORDER BY p.probability DESC;
```

This query will retrieve the object IDs, right ascension, declination, number of detections, and the probability of being an RR Lyrae star for objects that meet the specified criteria.

This database serves as a repository for information about individual spatial objects, encompassing various statistics, properties, detections, and features observed by survey telescopes.
The tables within the database are categorized into three types: time and band independent (e.g., object, probability), time-independent (e.g., magstats), and time and band-dependent (e.g., detection). Your role involves carefully analyzing user requests, considering the specifics of the given tables. It is crucial to pay attention to explicit conditions outlined by the user and always maintain awareness of the broader context.
ALeRCE processes data from the alert stream of the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF), so unless a specific catalog is mentioned, the data is from ZTF, including the object, candidate and filter identifiers, and other relevant information.  
Be thorough in understanding and addressing the user's request, taking into account both explicit conditions and the overall context for effective communication and assistance.

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);


CREATE TABLE dataquality (
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique identifier for the subtraction candidate */
    oid VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* unique identifier for this object */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* Filter ID (1=g; 2=r; 3=i) */
    xpos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* x-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    ypos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* y-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    chipsf DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Reduced chi-square for PSF-fit */
    sky DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Local sky background estimate [DN] */
    fwhm DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Full Width Half Max assuming a Gaussian core, from SExtractor [pixels] */
    classtar DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Star/Galaxy classification score from SExtractor */
    mindtoedge DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Distance to nearest edge in image [pixels] */
    seeratio DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: difffwhm / fwhm */
    aimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat major axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    bimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat minor axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    aimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: aimage / fwhm */
    bimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: bimage / fwhm */
    nneg INTEGER, /* number of negative pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    nbad INTEGER, /* number of prior-tagged bad pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    sumrat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: sum(pixels) / sum(abs(pixels)) in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp where stamp is first median-filtered to mitigate outliers */
    scorr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Peak-pixel signal-to-noise ratio in point source matched-filtered detection image */
    dsnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: D/stddev(D) on event position where D = difference image */
    ssnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: S/stddev(S) on event position where S = image of convolution: D (x) PSF(D) */
    magzpsci DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point for photometry estimates [mag] */
    magzpsciunc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point uncertainty (in magzpsci) [mag] */
    magzpscirms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS (deviation from average) in all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    nmatches INTEGER, /* Number of PS1 photometric calibrators used to calibrate science image from science image processing */
    clrcoeff DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient from linear fit from photometric calibration of science image */
    clrcounc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient uncertainty from linear fit (corresponding to clrcoeff) */
    zpclrcov DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Covariance in magzpsci and clrcoeff from science image processing [mag^2] */
    zpmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point from median of all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    clrmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Median color of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag]: for filter (fid) = 1, 2, 3, PS1 color used = g-r, g-r, r-i respectively */
    clrrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS color (deviation from average) of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag] */
    exptime DOUBLE PRECISION /* Integration time of camera exposure [sec] */
    FOREIGN KEY (candid, oid) REFERENCES detection(candid, oid)
);

# As a SQL expert with a willingness to assist users, you are tasked with crafting a PostgreSQL query for the Automatic Learning for the Rapid Classification of Events (ALeRCE) Database in 2023. This database serves as a repository for information about individual spatial objects, encompassing various statistics, properties, detections, and features observed by survey telescopes.
The tables within the database are categorized into three types: time and band independent (e.g., object, probability), time-independent (e.g., magstats), and time and band-dependent (e.g., detection). Your role involves carefully analyzing user requests, considering the specifics of the given tables. It is crucial to pay attention to explicit conditions outlined by the user and always maintain awareness of the broader context.
ALeRCE processes data from the alert stream of the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF), so unless a specific catalog is mentioned, the data is from ZTF, including the object, candidate and filter identifiers, and other relevant information.  
Be thorough in understanding and addressing the user's request, taking into account both explicit conditions and the overall context for effective communication and assistance.


# The Database has the following tables that can be used to generate the SQL query:

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);


CREATE TABLE dataquality (
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique identifier for the subtraction candidate */
    oid VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* unique identifier for this object */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* Filter ID (1=g; 2=r; 3=i) */
    xpos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* x-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    ypos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* y-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    chipsf DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Reduced chi-square for PSF-fit */
    sky DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Local sky background estimate [DN] */
    fwhm DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Full Width Half Max assuming a Gaussian core, from SExtractor [pixels] */
    classtar DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Star/Galaxy classification score from SExtractor */
    mindtoedge DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Distance to nearest edge in image [pixels] */
    seeratio DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: difffwhm / fwhm */
    aimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat major axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    bimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat minor axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    aimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: aimage / fwhm */
    bimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: bimage / fwhm */
    nneg INTEGER, /* number of negative pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    nbad INTEGER, /* number of prior-tagged bad pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    sumrat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: sum(pixels) / sum(abs(pixels)) in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp where stamp is first median-filtered to mitigate outliers */
    scorr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Peak-pixel signal-to-noise ratio in point source matched-filtered detection image */
    dsnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: D/stddev(D) on event position where D = difference image */
    ssnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: S/stddev(S) on event position where S = image of convolution: D (x) PSF(D) */
    magzpsci DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point for photometry estimates [mag] */
    magzpsciunc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point uncertainty (in magzpsci) [mag] */
    magzpscirms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS (deviation from average) in all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    nmatches INTEGER, /* Number of PS1 photometric calibrators used to calibrate science image from science image processing */
    clrcoeff DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient from linear fit from photometric calibration of science image */
    clrcounc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient uncertainty from linear fit (corresponding to clrcoeff) */
    zpclrcov DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Covariance in magzpsci and clrcoeff from science image processing [mag^2] */
    zpmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point from median of all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    clrmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Median color of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag]: for filter (fid) = 1, 2, 3, PS1 color used = g-r, g-r, r-i respectively */
    clrrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS color (deviation from average) of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag] */
    exptime DOUBLE PRECISION /* Integration time of camera exposure [sec] */
    FOREIGN KEY (candid, oid) REFERENCES detection(candid, oid)
);




## DEFAULT CONDITIONS YOU NEED TO SET

### Important points to consider
- If the user doesn't specify explicit columns or information that is not in a column, choose all the columns, for example by using the “SELECT *” SQL statement, from ALL the tables used, including the ones from the sub-queries.

- Mantain the exact class names as they are in the database, marked with single quotes, for example, 'SNIa'.

DON'T include anything else in your answer. If you want to add comments, use the SQL comment format inside the query.

# Use the next decomposed planification to write the query:
To generate the PostgreSQL query that fulfills the user's request, we can follow these steps:

1. **Identify the Relevant Tables**: The main tables required for this query are `object` and `magstat`. The `object` table contains the overall object information, while the `magstat` table has the details about the object's magnitudes and colors.

2. **Filter by Time Range**: The user wants to retrieve objects whose first detection happened in September. We can use the `firstmjd` column from the `object` table to filter the objects based on the provided MJD date range for September.

   ```
   WHERE object.firstmjd BETWEEN 60188.0 AND 60217.0
   ```

3. **Filter by Magnitude and Color Criteria**: The user wants to retrieve objects with a peak magnitude above 19 and a g-r color at maximum below 1. We can use the `magmax_corr` and `g_r_max_corr` columns from the `object` table to apply these filters.

   ```
   AND object.magmax_corr > 19
   AND object.g_r_max_corr < 1
   ```

4. **Filter by Object Type**: The user is interested in Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia). We can use the `probability` table and filter for the 'SNIa' class with the highest probability (ranking = 1) and the 'lc_classifier' classifier.

   ```
   AND probability.class_name = 'SNIa'
   AND probability.ranking = 1
   AND probability.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'
   ```

5. **Select the Desired Columns**: The user wants to retrieve the object identifier, the maximum g-r difference, the maximum magnitude, and the filter id. We can select these columns from the `object` and `magstat` tables.

   ```
   SELECT object.oid, object.g_r_max_corr, magstat.magmax_corr, magstat.fid
   ```

6. **Join the Tables**: To get the required information, we need to join the `object` and `magstat` tables on the `oid` column. We can use an INNER JOIN for this.

   ```
   FROM object
   INNER JOIN magstat ON object.oid = magstat.oid
   ```

7. **Putting it All Together**: Combining the steps above, the final query would look like this:

   ```
   SELECT object.oid, object.g_r_max_corr, magstat.magmax_corr, magstat.fid
   FROM object
   INNER JOIN magstat ON object.oid = magstat.oid
   WHERE object.firstmjd BETWEEN 60188.0 AND 60217.0
     AND object.magmax_corr > 19
     AND object.g_r_max_corr < 1
     AND probability.class_name = 'SNIa'
     AND probability.ranking = 1
     AND probability.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'
   ```

This query will retrieve the requested information for Type Ia supernovae that meet the specified criteria from the ALeRCE database.

    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);


CREATE TABLE dataquality (
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique identifier for the subtraction candidate */
    oid VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* unique identifier for this object */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* Filter ID (1=g; 2=r; 3=i) */
    xpos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* x-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    ypos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* y-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    chipsf DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Reduced chi-square for PSF-fit */
    sky DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Local sky background estimate [DN] */
    fwhm DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Full Width Half Max assuming a Gaussian core, from SExtractor [pixels] */
    classtar DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Star/Galaxy classification score from SExtractor */
    mindtoedge DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Distance to nearest edge in image [pixels] */
    seeratio DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: difffwhm / fwhm */
    aimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat major axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    bimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat minor axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    aimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: aimage / fwhm */
    bimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: bimage / fwhm */
    nneg INTEGER, /* number of negative pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    nbad INTEGER, /* number of prior-tagged bad pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    sumrat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: sum(pixels) / sum(abs(pixels)) in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp where stamp is first median-filtered to mitigate outliers */
    scorr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Peak-pixel signal-to-noise ratio in point source matched-filtered detection image */
    dsnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: D/stddev(D) on event position where D = difference image */
    ssnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: S/stddev(S) on event position where S = image of convolution: D (x) PSF(D) */
    magzpsci DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point for photometry estimates [mag] */
    magzpsciunc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point uncertainty (in magzpsci) [mag] */
    magzpscirms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS (deviation from average) in all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    nmatches INTEGER, /* Number of PS1 photometric calibrators used to calibrate science image from science image processing */
    clrcoeff DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient from linear fit from photometric calibration of science image */
    clrcounc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient uncertainty from linear fit (corresponding to clrcoeff) */
    zpclrcov DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Covariance in magzpsci and clrcoeff from science image processing [mag^2] */
    zpmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point from median of all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    clrmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Median color of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag]: for filter (fid) = 1, 2, 3, PS1 color used = g-r, g-r, r-i respectively */
    clrrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS color (deviation from average) of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag] */
    exptime DOUBLE PRECISION /* Integration time of camera exposure [sec] */
    FOREIGN KEY (candid, oid) REFERENCES detection(candid, oid)
);

The tables within the database are categorized into three types: time and band independent (e.g., object, probability), time-independent (e.g., magstats), and time and band-dependent (e.g., detection). Your role involves carefully analyzing user requests, considering the specifics of the given tables. It is crucial to pay attention to explicit conditions outlined by the user and always maintain awareness of the broader context.
ALeRCE processes data from the alert stream of the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF), so unless a specific catalog is mentioned, the data is from ZTF, including the object, candidate and filter identifiers, and other relevant information.  
Be thorough in understanding and addressing the user's request, taking into account both explicit conditions and the overall context for effective communication and assistance.


# The Database has the following tables that can be used to generate the SQL query:

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);


CREATE TABLE dataquality (
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique identifier for the subtraction candidate */
    oid VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* unique identifier for this object */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* Filter ID (1=g; 2=r; 3=i) */
    xpos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* x-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    ypos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* y-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    chipsf DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Reduced chi-square for PSF-fit */
    sky DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Local sky background estimate [DN] */
    fwhm DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Full Width Half Max assuming a Gaussian core, from SExtractor [pixels] */
    classtar DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Star/Galaxy classification score from SExtractor */
    mindtoedge DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Distance to nearest edge in image [pixels] */
    seeratio DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: difffwhm / fwhm */
    aimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat major axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    bimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat minor axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    aimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: aimage / fwhm */
    bimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: bimage / fwhm */
    nneg INTEGER, /* number of negative pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    nbad INTEGER, /* number of prior-tagged bad pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    sumrat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: sum(pixels) / sum(abs(pixels)) in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp where stamp is first median-filtered to mitigate outliers */
    scorr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Peak-pixel signal-to-noise ratio in point source matched-filtered detection image */
    dsnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: D/stddev(D) on event position where D = difference image */
    ssnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: S/stddev(S) on event position where S = image of convolution: D (x) PSF(D) */
    magzpsci DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point for photometry estimates [mag] */
    magzpsciunc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point uncertainty (in magzpsci) [mag] */
    magzpscirms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS (deviation from average) in all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    nmatches INTEGER, /* Number of PS1 photometric calibrators used to calibrate science image from science image processing */
    clrcoeff DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient from linear fit from photometric calibration of science image */
    clrcounc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient uncertainty from linear fit (corresponding to clrcoeff) */
    zpclrcov DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Covariance in magzpsci and clrcoeff from science image processing [mag^2] */
    zpmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point from median of all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    clrmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Median color of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag]: for filter (fid) = 1, 2, 3, PS1 color used = g-r, g-r, r-i respectively */
    clrrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS color (deviation from average) of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag] */
    exptime DOUBLE PRECISION /* Integration time of camera exposure [sec] */
    FOREIGN KEY (candid, oid) REFERENCES detection(candid, oid)
);

To generate the PostgreSQL query that fulfills the user's request, we can follow these steps:

1. **Identify the Relevant Tables and Columns:**
   - The main table is `object`, which contains the general information about the astronomical objects.
   - The `probability` table contains the classification probabilities for each object.
   - The `feature` table contains the various features calculated for each object, including the photometric period and variation amplitude.

2. **Define the Query Requirements:**
   - The user wants to retrieve objects that are likely to be Young Stellar Objects (YSOs), with a probability greater than 0.7.
   - The objects should also have some periodicity, with a photometric period between 3 and 10 days, and a variation amplitude greater than 0.5 magnitudes.
   - The results should be sorted in descending order by the probability of being a YSO.
   - The desired output includes the object identifier, the probability, the feature name, value, filter ID, and the feature version.

3. **Construct the Query:**
   - Start with the `probability` table to filter for objects with a YSO classification probability greater than 0.7.
   - Join the `probability` table with the `object` table to access the object-level information.
   - Join the `feature` table to retrieve the relevant features (photometric period and variation amplitude).
   - Apply the filters for the photometric period (between 3 and 10 days) and variation amplitude (greater than 0.5 magnitudes).
   - Sort the results in descending order by the YSO probability.
   - Select the desired output columns: `object.oid`, `probability.probability`, `feature.name`, `feature.value`, `feature.fid`, and `feature.version`.

The detailed steps to generate the SQL query are as follows:

1. Select from the `probability` table where the `class_name` is `'YSO'` and the `probability` is greater than 0.7, and the `ranking` is 1 (most likely class).
2. Join the `probability` table with the `object` table on the `oid` column to access the object-level information.
3. Join the `feature` table with the previous result to retrieve the relevant features (photometric period and variation amplitude).
4. Filter the `feature` table to only include rows where the `name` is either `'Period_band'` (for the photometric period) or `'Amplitude'` (for the variation amplitude), and the `value` for the period is between 3 and 10 days, and the `value` for the amplitude is greater than 0.5 magnitudes.
5. Order the final result by the `probability.probability` column in descending order.
6. Select the desired output columns: `object.oid`, `probability.probability`, `feature.name`, `feature.value`, `feature.fid`, and `feature.version`.

By following these steps, you can generate the SQL query that fulfills the user's request to retrieve objects that are likely to be YSOs and have the specified photometric period and variation amplitude, sorted by the YSO probability in descending order.

# As a SQL expert with a willingness to assist users, you are tasked with crafting a PostgreSQL query for the Automatic Learning for the Rapid Classification of Events (ALeRCE) Database in 2023. This database serves as a repository for information about individual spatial objects, encompassing various statistics, properties, detections, and features observed by survey telescopes.
The tables within the database are categorized into three types: time and band independent (e.g., object, probability), time-independent (e.g., magstats), and time and band-dependent (e.g., detection). Your role involves carefully analyzing user requests, considering the specifics of the given tables. It is crucial to pay attention to explicit conditions outlined by the user and always maintain awareness of the broader context.
ALeRCE processes data from the alert stream of the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF), so unless a specific catalog is mentioned, the data is from ZTF, including the object, candidate and filter identifiers, and other relevant information.

# The Database has the following tables that can be used to generate the SQL query:

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);


CREATE TABLE dataquality (
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique identifier for the subtraction candidate */
    oid VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* unique identifier for this object */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* Filter ID (1=g; 2=r; 3=i) */
    xpos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* x-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    ypos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* y-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    chipsf DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Reduced chi-square for PSF-fit */
    sky DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Local sky background estimate [DN] */
    fwhm DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Full Width Half Max assuming a Gaussian core, from SExtractor [pixels] */
    classtar DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Star/Galaxy classification score from SExtractor */
    mindtoedge DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Distance to nearest edge in image [pixels] */
    seeratio DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: difffwhm / fwhm */
    aimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat major axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    bimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat minor axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    aimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: aimage / fwhm */
    bimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: bimage / fwhm */
    nneg INTEGER, /* number of negative pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    nbad INTEGER, /* number of prior-tagged bad pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    sumrat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: sum(pixels) / sum(abs(pixels)) in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp where stamp is first median-filtered to mitigate outliers */
    scorr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Peak-pixel signal-to-noise ratio in point source matched-filtered detection image */
    dsnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: D/stddev(D) on event position where D = difference image */
    ssnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: S/stddev(S) on event position where S = image of convolution: D (x) PSF(D) */
    magzpsci DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point for photometry estimates [mag] */
    magzpsciunc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point uncertainty (in magzpsci) [mag] */
    magzpscirms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS (deviation from average) in all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    nmatches INTEGER, /* Number of PS1 photometric calibrators used to calibrate science image from science image processing */
    clrcoeff DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient from linear fit from photometric calibration of science image */
    clrcounc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient uncertainty from linear fit (corresponding to clrcoeff) */
    zpclrcov DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Covariance in magzpsci and clrcoeff from science image processing [mag^2] */
    zpmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point from median of all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    clrmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Median color of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag]: for filter (fid) = 1, 2, 3, PS1 color used = g-r, g-r, r-i respectively */
    clrrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS color (deviation from average) of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag] */
    exptime DOUBLE PRECISION /* Integration time of camera exposure [sec] */
    FOREIGN KEY (candid, oid) REFERENCES detection(candid, oid)
