# As a SQL expert with a willingness to assist users, you are tasked with crafting a PostgreSQL query for the Automatic Learning for the Rapid Classification of Events (ALeRCE) Database in 2023. This database serves as a repository for information about individual spatial objects, encompassing various statistics, properties, detections, and features observed by survey telescopes.
The tables within the database are categorized into three types: time and band independent (e.g., object, probability), time-independent (e.g., magstats), and time and band-dependent (e.g., detection). Your role involves carefully analyzing user requests, considering the specifics of the given tables. It is crucial to pay attention to explicit conditions outlined by the user and always maintain awareness of the broader context.
ALeRCE processes data from the alert stream of the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF), so unless a specific catalog is mentioned, the data is from ZTF, including the object, candidate and filter identifiers, and other relevant information.  
Be thorough in understanding and addressing the user's request, taking into account both explicit conditions and the overall context for effective communication and assistance.


# The Database has the following tables that can be used to generate the SQL query:

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);


CREATE TABLE dataquality (
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique identifier for the subtraction candidate */
    oid VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* unique identifier for this object */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* Filter ID (1=g; 2=r; 3=i) */
    xpos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* x-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    ypos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* y-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    chipsf DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Reduced chi-square for PSF-fit */
    sky DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Local sky background estimate [DN] */
    fwhm DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Full Width Half Max assuming a Gaussian core, from SExtractor [pixels] */
    classtar DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Star/Galaxy classification score from SExtractor */
    mindtoedge DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Distance to nearest edge in image [pixels] */
    seeratio DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: difffwhm / fwhm */
    aimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat major axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    bimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat minor axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    aimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: aimage / fwhm */
    bimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: bimage / fwhm */
    nneg INTEGER, /* number of negative pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    nbad INTEGER, /* number of prior-tagged bad pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    sumrat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: sum(pixels) / sum(abs(pixels)) in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp where stamp is first median-filtered to mitigate outliers */
    scorr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Peak-pixel signal-to-noise ratio in point source matched-filtered detection image */
    dsnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: D/stddev(D) on event position where D = difference image */
    ssnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: S/stddev(S) on event position where S = image of convolution: D (x) PSF(D) */
    magzpsci DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point for photometry estimates [mag] */
    magzpsciunc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point uncertainty (in magzpsci) [mag] */
    magzpscirms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS (deviation from average) in all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    nmatches INTEGER, /* Number of PS1 photometric calibrators used to calibrate science image from science image processing */
    clrcoeff DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient from linear fit from photometric calibration of science image */
    clrcounc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient uncertainty from linear fit (corresponding to clrcoeff) */
    zpclrcov DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Covariance in magzpsci and clrcoeff from science image processing [mag^2] */
    zpmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point from median of all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    clrmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Median color of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag]: for filter (fid) = 1, 2, 3, PS1 color used = g-r, g-r, r-i respectively */
    clrrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS color (deviation from average) of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag] */
    exptime DOUBLE PRECISION /* Integration time of camera exposure [sec] */
    FOREIGN KEY (candid, oid) REFERENCES detection(candid, oid)

To generate the PostgreSQL query that fulfills the user's request, we can follow these steps:

1. **Identify the Relevant Tables**: The main tables involved in this query are `object` and `feature`. The `probability` table will also be needed to retrieve the light curve classifier data.

2. **Formulate the Query Requirements**:
   - Filter the `object` table to find objects where the `deltajd` (difference between last and first detection date) is greater than 1 day.
   - Join the `feature` table to find the objects where the `LinearTrend` feature value is greater than 5.
   - Join the `probability` table to retrieve the light curve classifier data (class, probability, and classifier version) with ranking 1.
   - Select the desired columns: `oid` (ZTF identifier), `ndet` (number of detections), `classifier_version`, `class_name`, `probability`, `value` (LinearTrend feature value), and `fid` (filter identifier).
   - Limit the results to a maximum of 10 rows.

3. **Design the Query**:
   ```sql
   SELECT
       o.oid,
       o.ndet,
       p.classifier_version,
       p.class_name,
       p.probability,
       f.value,
       f.fid
   FROM object o
   INNER JOIN feature f ON o.oid = f.oid
   INNER JOIN probability p ON o.oid = p.oid
   WHERE
       o.deltajd > 1
       AND f.name = 'LinearTrend'
       AND f.value > 5
       AND p.ranking = 1
       AND p.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'
   ORDER BY f.value DESC
   LIMIT 10;
   ```

1. Start with the `object` table to filter for objects with `deltajd` greater than 1 day.

4. Select the desired columns from the joined tables.
5. Order the results by the `LinearTrend` feature value in descending order.
6. Limit the results to a maximum of 10 rows.

   - Limit the output to a maximum of 10 rows.

   ```

       o.oid,
       o.ndet,
       p.classifier_version,
       p.class_name,
       p.probability,
       f.value,
       f.fid
   FROM object o
   INNER JOIN feature f ON o.oid = f.oid
   INNER JOIN probability p ON o.oid = p.oid
   WHERE
       o.deltajd > 1
       AND f.name = 'LinearTrend'
       AND f.value > 5
       AND p.ranking = 1
       AND p.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'
   LIMIT 10;
   ```

This query will retrieve the requested information from the ALeRCE database, including the ZTF object identifier, number of detections, light curve classifier version, class name, probability, `LinearTrend` feature value, and filter identifier for up to 10 objects that meet the specified criteria.

# Use the next decomposed planification to write the query:
To generate the PostgreSQL query that fulfills the user's request, we can follow these steps:

1. **Identify the Relevant Tables**: The main tables required for this query are 'probability', 'object', 'xmatch', and 'allwise'.

2. **Establish the Query Requirements**:
   - The user wants to find at most 200 distinct ZTF objects.
   - The objects should have a probability greater than 0.7 of being classified as a QSO by the 'lc_classifier'.
   - The query should return all columns from the 'xmatch' and 'allwise' tables for the selected objects.

3. **Design the Query**:
   a. Start with the 'probability' table to filter the objects based on the classification criteria:
      - Use a `WHERE` clause to select only the rows where `probability.class_name = 'QSO'` and `probability.probability > 0.7`.
      - Limit the results to the top 200 rows using `LIMIT 200`.
      - Select the `oid` column from the 'probability' table to get the ZTF object IDs.
   b. Join the filtered 'probability' table with the 'object' table to access the additional object information:
      - Use an `INNER JOIN` between the 'probability' and 'object' tables on the `oid` column.
   c. Join the resulting table with the 'xmatch' and 'allwise' tables to retrieve the requested information:
      - Use `INNER JOIN` clauses to connect the 'object' table with the 'xmatch' and 'allwise' tables, matching on the `oid` column for 'xmatch' and the `oid_catalog` column for 'allwise'.
   d. Select all columns from the 'xmatch' and 'allwise' tables in the final query.

4. **Document the Query**:
   - Add comments to explain the purpose of each step in the query.
   - Describe any assumptions or limitations of the query.

The final query would look something like this (without the actual SQL code):

```
-- Find at most 200 distinct ZTF objects that have a probability larger than 0.7 of being a QSO in the light curve classifier
-- Return all columns from the 'xmatch' and 'allwise' tables for such objects

-- 1. Filter the 'probability' table to get the top 200 QSO candidates
SELECT p.oid
FROM probability p
WHERE p.class_name = 'QSO' AND p.probability > 0.7
ORDER BY p.probability DESC
LIMIT 200

-- 2. Join the filtered 'probability' table with the 'object' table to access additional object information
INNER JOIN object o ON p.oid = o.oid

-- 3. Join the resulting table with the 'xmatch' and 'allwise' tables to retrieve the requested information
INNER JOIN xmatch x ON o.oid = x.oid
INNER JOIN allwise a ON x.oid_catalog = a.oid_catalog

-- 4. Select all columns from the 'xmatch' and 'allwise' tables
SELECT x.*, a.*
```

This query first filters the 'probability' table to get the top 200 QSO candidates, then joins the filtered results with the 'object', 'xmatch', and 'allwise' tables to retrieve the requested information. To generate the PostgreSQL query to retrieve the requested information, the following steps can be followed:

1. **Identify the Relevant Tables**: The main tables required for this query are 'probability', 'object', 'xmatch', and 'allwise'.

   - Join the 'probability' table with the 'object' table to access the object-level information.
   - Join the resulting table with the 'xmatch' table to retrieve the cross-match data.
   - Join the resulting table with the 'allwise' table to retrieve the AllWISE catalog data.

```
SELECT DISTINCT ON (o.oid) x.*, a.*
FROM probability p
JOIN object o ON p.oid = o.oid
JOIN xmatch x ON o.oid = x.oid
JOIN allwise a ON x.oid_catalog = a.oid_catalog
WHERE p.class_name = 'QSO' AND p.probability > 0.7 AND p.ranking = 1 AND p.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'
ORDER BY o.oid, p.probability DESC
LIMIT 200;
```

# As a SQL expert with a willingness to assist users, you are tasked with crafting a PostgreSQL query for the Automatic Learning for the Rapid Classification of Events (ALeRCE) Database in 2023. This database serves as a repository for information about individual spatial objects, encompassing various statistics, properties, detections, and features observed by survey telescopes.
The tables within the database are categorized into three types: time and band independent (e.g., object, probability), time-independent (e.g., magstats), and time and band-dependent (e.g., detection). # The Database has the following tables that can be used to generate the SQL query:

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);


CREATE TABLE dataquality (
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique identifier for the subtraction candidate */
    oid VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* unique identifier for this object */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* Filter ID (1=g; 2=r; 3=i) */
    xpos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* x-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    ypos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* y-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    chipsf DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Reduced chi-square for PSF-fit */
    sky DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Local sky background estimate [DN] */
    fwhm DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Full Width Half Max assuming a Gaussian core, from SExtractor [pixels] */
    classtar DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Star/Galaxy classification score from SExtractor */
    mindtoedge DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Distance to nearest edge in image [pixels] */
    seeratio DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: difffwhm / fwhm */
    aimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat major axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    bimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat minor axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    aimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: aimage / fwhm */
    bimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: bimage / fwhm */
    nneg INTEGER, /* number of negative pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    nbad INTEGER, /* number of prior-tagged bad pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    sumrat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: sum(pixels) / sum(abs(pixels)) in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp where stamp is first median-filtered to mitigate outliers */
    scorr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Peak-pixel signal-to-noise ratio in point source matched-filtered detection image */
    dsnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: D/stddev(D) on event position where D = difference image */
    ssnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: S/stddev(S) on event position where S = image of convolution: D (x) PSF(D) */
    magzpsci DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point for photometry estimates [mag] */
    magzpsciunc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point uncertainty (in magzpsci) [mag] */
    magzpscirms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS (deviation from average) in all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    nmatches INTEGER, /* Number of PS1 photometric calibrators used to calibrate science image from science image processing */
    clrcoeff DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient from linear fit from photometric calibration of science image */
    clrcounc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient uncertainty from linear fit (corresponding to clrcoeff) */
    zpclrcov DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Covariance in magzpsci and clrcoeff from science image processing [mag^2] */
    zpmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point from median of all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    clrmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Median color of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag]: for filter (fid) = 1, 2, 3, PS1 color used = g-r, g-r, r-i respectively */
    clrrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS color (deviation from average) of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag] */

    FOREIGN KEY (candid, oid) REFERENCES detection(candid, oid)

# Use the next decomposed planification to write the query:
To generate the PostgreSQL query that fulfills the user's request, we can follow these steps:

1. **Identify the Relevant Tables**:
   - The main tables required are `probability`, `xmatch`, and `allwise`.
   - The `probability` table contains the classification probabilities and rankings.
   - The `xmatch` table contains the cross-match information between ZTF objects and other catalogs.
   - The `allwise` table contains the WISE photometric data for the objects.

2. **Define the Query Requirements**:
   - The user wants to find ZTF objects that have a probability larger than 0.5 of being a long period variable (LPV) in the light curve classifier.
   - The user also wants to filter the results to only include objects with a WISE W1 magnitude between 7 and 8.
   - The user wants to return all columns from the `probability`, `xmatch`, and `allwise` tables for the matching objects.
   - The user wants to limit the result to a maximum of 100 rows.

3. **Construct the Query**:
   - Start with the `probability` table as the main table, since it contains the classification information.
   - Add a `WHERE` clause to filter for objects with a probability greater than 0.5 for the 'LPV' class in the 'lc_classifier'.
   - Join the `xmatch` table to get the cross-match information.
   - Join the `allwise` table to get the WISE photometric data.
   - Add a `WHERE` clause to filter for objects with a WISE W1 magnitude between 7 and 8.
   - Select all columns from the three tables using `SELECT *`.
   - Add a `LIMIT 100` clause to restrict the result to a maximum of 100 rows.

The final query would look something like this (without the actual SQL code):

```
SELECT *
FROM probability p
INNER JOIN xmatch x ON p.oid = x.oid
INNER JOIN allwise a ON x.oid_catalog = a.oid_catalog
WHERE p.probability > 0.5
  AND p.class_name = 'LPV'
  AND p.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'
  AND a.w1mpro BETWEEN 7 AND 8
LIMIT 100;
```

This query first finds the objects with a high probability of being an LPV in the light curve classifier, then joins the cross-match and ALLWISE data to filter for the desired WISE magnitude range, and finally returns all the columns from the three tables for the matching objects, limiting the result to 100 rows.

This database serves as a repository for information about individual spatial objects, encompassing various statistics, properties, detections, and features observed by survey telescopes.
The tables within the database are categorized into three types: time and band independent (e.g., object, probability), time-independent (e.g., magstats), and time and band-dependent (e.g., detection). Your role involves carefully analyzing user requests, considering the specifics of the given tables.     firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);


CREATE TABLE dataquality (
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique identifier for the subtraction candidate */
    oid VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* unique identifier for this object */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* Filter ID (1=g; 2=r; 3=i) */
    xpos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* x-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    ypos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* y-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    chipsf DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Reduced chi-square for PSF-fit */
    sky DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Local sky background estimate [DN] */
    fwhm DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Full Width Half Max assuming a Gaussian core, from SExtractor [pixels] */
    classtar DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Star/Galaxy classification score from SExtractor */
    mindtoedge DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Distance to nearest edge in image [pixels] */
    seeratio DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: difffwhm / fwhm */
    aimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat major axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    bimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat minor axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    aimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: aimage / fwhm */
    bimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: bimage / fwhm */
    nneg INTEGER, /* number of negative pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    nbad INTEGER, /* number of prior-tagged bad pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    sumrat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: sum(pixels) / sum(abs(pixels)) in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp where stamp is first median-filtered to mitigate outliers */
    scorr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Peak-pixel signal-to-noise ratio in point source matched-filtered detection image */
    dsnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: D/stddev(D) on event position where D = difference image */
    ssnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: S/stddev(S) on event position where S = image of convolution: D (x) PSF(D) */
    magzpsci DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point for photometry estimates [mag] */
    magzpsciunc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point uncertainty (in magzpsci) [mag] */
    magzpscirms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS (deviation from average) in all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    nmatches INTEGER, /* Number of PS1 photometric calibrators used to calibrate science image from science image processing */
    clrcoeff DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient from linear fit from photometric calibration of science image */
    clrcounc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient uncertainty from linear fit (corresponding to clrcoeff) */
    zpclrcov DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Covariance in magzpsci and clrcoeff from science image processing [mag^2] */
    zpmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point from median of all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    clrmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Median color of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag]: for filter (fid) = 1, 2, 3, PS1 color used = g-r, g-r, r-i respectively */
    clrrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS color (deviation from average) of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag] */
    exptime DOUBLE PRECISION /* Integration time of camera exposure [sec] */
    FOREIGN KEY (candid, oid) REFERENCES detection(candid, oid)

   - The closest PS1 objects for these ZTF objects should have a star/galaxy score greater than 0.8.
   - The query should return all columns from the `probability` and `ps1_ztf` tables.
   - The result should be limited to a maximum of 100 rows.

3. **Design the Query**:
   - Start with the `probability` table as the main table, since it contains the classification probabilities.
   - Add a `WHERE` clause to filter for the specific classifier name, version, and probability threshold:
     - `probability.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'`
     - `probability.classifier_version = 'hierarchical_rf_1.1.0'`
     - `probability.probability > 0.6`
     - `probability.class_name IN ('CEP', 'DSCT', 'RRL')`

   - Add another `WHERE` clause to filter for PS1 sources with a star/galaxy score greater than 0.8:
     - `ps1_ztf.sgscore1 > 0.8 OR ps1_ztf.sgscore2 > 0.8 OR ps1_ztf.sgscore3 > 0.8`
   - Use the `LIMIT 100` clause to restrict the number of rows in the result set.

   - Describe any assumptions or limitations of the query, such as the fact that it only considers the top-ranked classification probability.

The final query would look something like this:

```sql
-- Retrieve ZTF objects with high probability of being Cepheid, Delta Scuti, or RR Lyrae,
-- and their closest PS1 sources have a star/galaxy score greater than 0.8.

FROM probability p
INNER JOIN ps1_ztf ps1 ON p.oid = ps1.oid
WHERE p.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'
  AND p.classifier_version = 'hierarchical_rf_1.1.0'
  AND p.probability > 0.6
  AND p.class_name IN ('CEP', 'DSCT', 'RRL')

LIMIT 100;
```

2. **Define the Temporary Table for Input Objects**:

   - The table should have columns for the identifier (`id`), right ascension (`obj_ra`), declination (`obj_dec`), and the search radius in degrees (`r_deg`).
   - The values for the two input objects are:
     - id_1: `RA=132.961`, `Dec=41.397`, `r_deg=0.0139` (5 arcsec)
     - id_2: `RA=139.01`, `Dec=41.5653`, `r_deg=0.0278` (10 arcsec)

3. **Join the Temporary Table with the `allwise` Table**:
   - Use an `INNER JOIN` to connect the temporary table with the `allwise` table, based on the spatial proximity conditions.
   - Utilize the Q3C functions to perform the spatial queries:
     - `q3c_join(allwise.ra, allwise.dec, input_table.obj_ra, input_table.obj_dec, input_table.r_deg)` to check if the ALLWISE object is within the specified search radius of the input object.

4. **Select the Desired Columns**:

```
  io.obj_dec,
  io.r_deg,
```

1. **Identify the Relevant Tables**: The main tables involved in this query are `object` and `ss_ztf`. The `object` table contains the general information about the ZTF objects, and the `ss_ztf` table contains the information about the closest known solar system objects.

2. **Define the Selection Criteria**: The user request is to find all MPC objects brighter than 19.2 mag for the given ZTF objects: 'ZTF20abmaqeh', 'ZTF18abwxduj', and 'ZTF19aactlln'. This means we need to:
   - Filter the `object` table to only include the specified ZTF objects.
   - Join the `object` and `ss_ztf` tables to get the information about the closest known solar system objects.
   - Add a condition to filter the solar system objects based on their magnitude being brighter than 19.2 mag.

3. **Determine the Columns to Retrieve**: The user request is to get the following columns:
   - Identifier in both ZTF and MPC (from `ss_ztf` table)
   - MPC magnitude (from `ss_ztf` table)

4. **Sort the Results**: The user request is to sort the results by MPC magnitude in descending order.

5. **Construct the Query**:
   - Start with a `SELECT` statement to retrieve the required columns from the `ss_ztf` table.
   - Add a `WHERE` clause to filter the `object` table for the specified ZTF objects.
   - Use an `INNER JOIN` to connect the `object` and `ss_ztf` tables based on the `oid` column.
   - Add a condition to filter the solar system objects based on the `ssmagnr` column being brighter than 19.2 mag.
   - Use the `ORDER BY` clause to sort the results by `ssmagnr` in descending order.

The final query would look something like this:

```sql
SELECT ss_ztf.oid, ss_ztf.ssnamenr, ss_ztf.ssmagnr
FROM object
INNER JOIN ss_ztf ON object.oid = ss_ztf.oid
WHERE object.oid IN ('ZTF20abmaqeh', 'ZTF18abwxduj', 'ZTF19aactlln')
  AND ss_ztf.ssmagnr < 19.2
ORDER BY ss_ztf.ssmagnr DESC;
```

This query will retrieve the requested information from the `ss_ztf` table, filtered for the specified ZTF objects and solar system objects brighter than 19.2 mag, and sorted by the MPC magnitude in descending order.

2. **Define the Selection Criteria**: The user request is to find all MPC objects brighter than 19.2 mag for the given ZTF objects: 'ZTF20abmaqeh', 'ZTF18abwxduj', and 'ZTF19aactlln'. This means we need to:

   - Join the `object` and `ss_ztf` tables to get the information about the closest known solar system objects.
   - Add a condition to filter the solar system objects based on their magnitude being brighter than 19.2 mag.

3. **Determine the Columns to Retrieve**: The user request is to get the following columns:

   - MPC magnitude (from `ss_ztf` table)

```sql
SELECT ss_ztf.oid, ss_ztf.ssnamenr, ss_ztf.ssmagnr
FROM object
INNER JOIN ss_ztf ON object.oid = ss_ztf.oid
WHERE object.oid IN ('ZTF20abmaqeh', 'ZTF18abwxduj', 'ZTF19aactlln')

ORDER BY ss_ztf.ssmagnr DESC;
```

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);


CREATE TABLE dataquality (
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique identifier for the subtraction candidate */
    oid VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* unique identifier for this object */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* Filter ID (1=g; 2=r; 3=i) */
    xpos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* x-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    ypos DOUBLE PRECISION, /* y-image position of candidate [pixels] */
    chipsf DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Reduced chi-square for PSF-fit */
    sky DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Local sky background estimate [DN] */
    fwhm DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Full Width Half Max assuming a Gaussian core, from SExtractor [pixels] */
    classtar DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Star/Galaxy classification score from SExtractor */
    mindtoedge DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Distance to nearest edge in image [pixels] */
    seeratio DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: difffwhm / fwhm */
    aimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat major axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    bimage DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Windowed profile RMS afloat minor axis from SExtractor [pixels] */
    aimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: aimage / fwhm */
    bimagerat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: bimage / fwhm */
    nneg INTEGER, /* number of negative pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    nbad INTEGER, /* number of prior-tagged bad pixels in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp */
    sumrat DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: sum(pixels) / sum(abs(pixels)) in a 5 x 5 pixel stamp where stamp is first median-filtered to mitigate outliers */
    scorr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Peak-pixel signal-to-noise ratio in point source matched-filtered detection image */
    dsnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: D/stddev(D) on event position where D = difference image */
    ssnrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Ratio: S/stddev(S) on event position where S = image of convolution: D (x) PSF(D) */
    magzpsci DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point for photometry estimates [mag] */
    magzpsciunc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point uncertainty (in magzpsci) [mag] */

    clrcoeff DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient from linear fit from photometric calibration of science image */
    clrcounc DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Color coefficient uncertainty from linear fit (corresponding to clrcoeff) */
    zpclrcov DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Covariance in magzpsci and clrcoeff from science image processing [mag^2] */
    zpmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Magnitude zero point from median of all differences between instrumental photometry and matched photometric calibrators from science image processing [mag] */
    clrmed DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Median color of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag]: for filter (fid) = 1, 2, 3, PS1 color used = g-r, g-r, r-i respectively */
    clrrms DOUBLE PRECISION, /* RMS color (deviation from average) of all PS1 photometric calibrators used from science image processing [mag] */
